Usually, but not always. In isolated, overwhelmingly working-class communities, the same mechanism encouraged local clergymen to support unions, as happened at Homestead, in the Pullman township, and in some mining villages. Likewise, clergymen without a slave-holding constituency had been more likely to support abolition, and many denominations had split along this line of economic interest
